instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
Hi, I have a board with this problem. I have measured some voltages and I have 12v but I have been able to detect that in <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> pin 1,2,5 and 6 I do not have 12v.

I only have 12v on F9700 and <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR>.

Any ideas ? Thank you

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"I have 12v"
Please, post exact voltage; 12.2V and 12.5V is totally different thing!

Do you get image, only missing backlight?
USB activity confirmed for sure?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
Welcome ! sorry im rude ! ok sorry

I have measured again and in all the points I have 12.5.

Rookie mistakes ...

I have image. Checked with a flick behind the screen in the apple logo I can see the question folder.

USB activity<--- EDIT: yes I have tried with an external monitor and the USB port works.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
OK, then your problem is only backlight related.

Check first <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>.
Also post diode mode to ground at both pins of <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> (red probe at ground); w/ and w/o LCD connected.
Inspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> for corrosion, especially A5 ball.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.25v
<DIODE>D9701</DIODE> w/o LCD value mode diode both pins 150 (red probe at ground); Pin1 386 Pin2 562

w/ LCD  both pins 160 (red probe at ground) Pin1 and pin2 continuity

Inspect <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> for corrosion, especially A5 ball. ---> This component is new. I asked a friend with great skill as an air welder to replace this component.

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL> = 12.42v

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
"<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> pin 1,2,5 and 6 I do not have 12v.
-----------------------
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = 0v
--------------------
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL> = 12.42v"
I force me to understand how this is possible...

We need accurate information, or we cannot help.

"w/ LCD  both pins 160 (red probe at ground) [B][U]Pin1 and pin2 continuity[/U][/B]"
What this mean, <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> measures short between pins?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
Ok first thing thanks for your patience.

I did the measurements without a screen connected, I think that was my error for the measurements.

I have measured again with LCD connected and <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> Pin 1 2 5 and 6 = 12.5v

The measurements for <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> I understand that I must put the red lead of the tester to ground and the black lead on pins 1 and 2 of the component. I'm confused?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
Yes, diode mode always with red probe on ground; but no power applied.

Now post <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
but no power applied. (I don't know it sorry im very noob)

<DIODE>D9701</DIODE> w/o LCD value mode diode both pins 150 (red probe at ground);

w/ LCD  pin1 425 pin2 643 both pines 187
w/o LCD pin1 424 pin2 641 both pines 185

<CHIP>U9701</CHIP> <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> I can't make measurements, I think the board has died or I made a mistake. Now no fan spin and sometimes it appears green light. I think it would be better to buy a reconditioned ebay.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message: If board had image before, shouldn't give up so fast.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
You are absolutely right. I have cleaned the board again and now the green light remains but the fan does not respond. I've seen a post that talks about the <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> component but mine seems fine.

Should I open a new post with this symptom? and continue this once the computer works again?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
Continue here.
Post basic voltages and signalfs from power on sequence.

Any history available for this board?

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
It works fine until one day it ran out of battery and did not turn on the screen again. It has no liquid damage. It could be used with an external screen.

You needed this to help me. I do not know if I have forgotten to put some measure.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.5
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> = 15V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 12.5 V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 16.7V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 12.5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V change 2,3 change 3,2 all time don’t stop
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V change 2 change 3,2 all time don’t stop
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.5
------------------
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 12.5 V"
Try to understand a schematic.
Do not waste time measuring the same power rail in different points.

Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and PCH's RTC signals; 4, in page 16.

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
sorry for delay I've been very sick.

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>= 0v 1,2v 3,2v flash
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>= 3.13v / 3.28 change flash

this part PCH's RTC signals; 4, in page 16. I don't understand. I beg your forgiveness but I don't understand what I should do with those signs. Refers to page 16 of the pdf files or at the bottom where the logo appears that puts page 16

threads.title: MBP <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont backlight
threads.message:
Page 16, inside PCH you can see RTC block marked.
There are 4 signals, apart of CLK.

Shouldn't be a problem there, as the board try to start (pulses).
Try to start in SMC bypass mode.
